cities.name: Bangkok

emergency.health_note: Bumrungrad International is the top-rated hospital for English speakers.

survival_kit.tipping: Not expected, but rounding up 20-50 THB is appreciated in taxis/cafes
survival_kit.toilets: Carry tissues; many public toilets are 'squat' style and charge 5-10 THB

transit_logic.payment_method: Rabbit Card for BTS; Cash for MRT and Street Food
transit_logic.etiquette: Give up seats for monks; Keep your head lower than elders

scam_alerts: The 'Grand Palace is closed today' lie by tuk-tuk drivers
Unmetered taxis outside major malls (insist on 'Meter, please')
Bird seed/bracelet 'gifts' that you are then forced to pay for
real_time_hacks: Use the 'Chao Phraya Express Boat' to bypass traffic for 15-30 THB
7-Eleven is your best friend for high-speed Wi-Fi and cheap AC breaks
Always carry a sarong/scarf for temple entry (shoulders/knees must be covered)

cities.name: Paris

emergency.health_note: American Hospital of Paris (Neuilly) is preferred for English speakers.

survival_kit.tap_water: Safe and high quality (Eau de Paris fountains are everywhere)
survival_kit.tipping: Service included (Service Compris). Round up €1-€2 for great service
survival_kit.toilets: Use 'Sanisettes' (free self-cleaning street pods) or museum restrooms

transit_logic.payment_method: Navigo Easy card (loaded via phone) or contactless (certain lines)
transit_logic.etiquette: Always start interactions with 'Bonjour'. Failing to do so is seen as a direct insult

scam_alerts: The 'Friendship Bracelet' men at Sacré-Cœur (keep hands in pockets)
The 'Found Ring' scam (they pretend you dropped a gold ring)
Petition signers who use the distraction to pickpocket
real_time_hacks: Download the 'Fontaines' app to find free sparkling water fountains
Dinner starts late (19:30+). Lunch is strictly 12:00-14:00
Avoid the 'Champs-Élysées' for food—expensive and low quality

cities.name: London

emergency.health_note: NHS 111 (dial 111) for urgent medical advice that isn't life-threatening.

survival_kit.tipping: 12.5% service charge often added to restaurant bills. Extra tip not needed
survival_kit.toilets: Download 'Flush' app. Department stores (Selfridges/Liberty) have best free toilets

transit_logic.payment_method: Strictly Contactless/Apple/Google Pay. Do not buy paper tickets
transit_logic.etiquette: Stand on the RIGHT on escalators. Do not make eye contact on the Tube

scam_alerts: Three-card Monte/shell games on Westminster Bridge
Fake 'Pedicabs' (bicycle rickshaws) charging £100+ for short rides
Unofficial 'airport transfer' touts in arrivals halls
real_time_hacks: Use the 'Hopper Fare': Unlimited bus journeys for £1.75 within one hour
Free views: Book 'Sky Garden' or 'Lookout' 3 weeks in advance for free city vistas
Tesco/Sainsbury's 'Meal Deal' is the cheapest lunch in the city (£3.50-£5.00)

cities.name: Tokyo

emergency.health_note: Few operators speak English; use translation app. Some hospitals require upfront payment.

survival_kit.tap_water: World-class; safe to drink from taps and many public fountains
survival_kit.power_plug: Type A & B (100V, 50Hz in Tokyo). US plugs work; EU/UK need adapter.
survival_kit.tipping: Not customary; can be seen as rude. No tipping in taxis or restaurants.
survival_kit.toilets: Mix of Western and high-tech washlets. Often free and spotless in stations.

transit_logic.primary_app: Google Maps or Japan Travel by Navitime; Suica/Pasmo in Apple Wallet
transit_logic.payment_method: Suica or Pasmo (IC cards) for trains/buses; cash still common in small shops
transit_logic.etiquette: No phones in priority seats; no talking on trains; queue neatly; no eating while walking

scam_alerts: Roppongi/Kabukicho bar touts leading to overpriced drinks and tab
Fake 'massage' or club invitations with hidden cover charges
Overpriced 'tourist' restaurants in main districts
real_time_hacks: Convenience stores (7-Eleven, Lawson) have excellent cheap meals and free Wi-Fi
Stand on the left on escalators in Tokyo (opposite of Osaka)
Last trains run around midnight—plan ahead or expect expensive taxis

cities.name: New York

emergency.health_note: 911 for all emergencies. ER visits are expensive; travel insurance recommended.

survival_kit.tap_water: Safe to drink (NYC tap is famously good). Refill at parks and stations.
survival_kit.power_plug: Type A & B (120V, 60Hz). EU/UK need adapter.
survival_kit.tipping: 15-20% in restaurants; $1-2 per drink at bars; tip cab/Uber drivers.
survival_kit.toilets: Starbucks and hotels; many subway stations have no or pay toilets.

transit_logic.primary_app: Citymapper or Google Maps; MTA website for subway status
transit_logic.payment_method: OMNY (tap) or MetroCard for subway/bus; contactless widely accepted
transit_logic.etiquette: Let people off before boarding; no eye contact; keep bags closed on crowded trains

scam_alerts: Fake 'CD' or 'mixtape' handoffs that you're then charged for
'Free' bracelet or photo with costumed characters in Times Square
Unofficial ticket sellers and 'skip-the-line' hustlers
real_time_hacks: Unlimited 7-day MetroCard pays off after ~12 rides
Free Staten Island Ferry for skyline views; avoid paid boat tours
Happy hour and prix-fixe lunches are the best value

cities.name: Rome

emergency.health_note: 112 is the single EU emergency number. Guardia Medica for non-life-threatening.

survival_kit.tap_water: Safe and excellent; use nasoni (street fountains) to refill for free
survival_kit.power_plug: Type L (230V, 50Hz). Adapter needed for US/UK.
survival_kit.tipping: Coperto may be on the bill. Round up or 5-10%; no obligation.
survival_kit.toilets: Pay toilets common (€0.50-1). Cafés expect a small purchase for WC use.

transit_logic.primary_app: Moovit or ATAC official app; Google Maps for walking
transit_logic.payment_method: Roma Pass or contactless on buses/trams; buy tickets before boarding
transit_logic.etiquette: Validate ticket on first use; dress modestly for churches

scam_alerts: 'Friendship bracelet' or rosemary forced into your hand then payment demanded
Gladiators outside Colosseum charging for photos
Restaurants with no prices or 'tourist menus' with hidden charges
real_time_hacks: Free drinking water from nasoni—bring a bottle
Book Colosseum/Forum online to skip lines and avoid touts
Aperitivo (6-9pm) often includes buffet for the price of a drink

cities.name: Barcelona

emergency.health_note: 112 is the single EU emergency number. CatSalut for public health.

survival_kit.tap_water: Safe to drink but often chlorinated; many prefer bottled.
survival_kit.power_plug: Type F (230V, 50Hz). Adapter needed for US/UK.
survival_kit.tipping: Not expected; round up or small change. Service may be included.
survival_kit.toilets: Pay toilets in some areas; cafés and museums are reliable.

transit_logic.primary_app: TMB (metro) or Citymapper; Google Maps for walking
transit_logic.payment_method: Hola BCN card or T-casual; contactless on buses
transit_logic.etiquette: Dress modestly for Sagrada Família; watch bags on Metro and La Rambla

scam_alerts: Pickpockets on La Rambla and Metro (distraction, bump-and-grab)
'Friendly' strangers offering rosemary or petition then demanding money
Fake 'police' asking to see wallet or documents
real_time_hacks: Book Sagrada Família and Park Güell online; skip long queues
T-casual gives 10 journeys on metro/bus for much less than single tickets
Eat away from La Rambla for better quality and prices

cities.name: Dubai

emergency.health_note: Private hospitals common; travel insurance recommended. Sharia applies; no PDA in public.

survival_kit.tap_water: Desalinated; technically safe but many prefer bottled. Hotels often provide bottles.
survival_kit.power_plug: Type G (230V, 50Hz). UK-style. Adapter for US/EU.
survival_kit.tipping: 10-15% in restaurants; AED 5-10 for valet/delivery. Not always expected in hotels.
survival_kit.toilets: Western and high standard in malls and hotels; free and clean.

transit_logic.primary_app: Careem or RTA Dubai (Nol card); Google Maps for directions
transit_logic.payment_method: Nol card for Metro/tram/bus; cards widely accepted elsewhere
transit_logic.etiquette: Women-only carriages on Metro; no eating/drinking on Metro; dress modestly

scam_alerts: Fake luxury goods in souks
Timeshare and property pitches with 'free' desert safari
Overpriced tours and activities sold on the street or beach
real_time_hacks: Nol card is refillable and works across Metro, tram, bus, and some taxis
Friday brunches are a Dubai institution but book in advance
Mall AC is fierce—carry a light layer

cities.name: Seoul

emergency.health_note: Tourist hotline 1330. Itaewon and Gangnam have hospitals with English-speaking staff.

survival_kit.tap_water: Safe (purified); refill at public stations and in subway.
survival_kit.power_plug: Type C & F (220V, 60Hz). Adapter for US flat pins.
survival_kit.tipping: Not expected; can be refused. No tipping in taxis or restaurants.
survival_kit.toilets: Western; clean in subway and malls. Often free.

transit_logic.primary_app: Kakao T (taxi), KakaoMap or Naver Map for transit and walking
transit_logic.payment_method: T-money for subway/bus; cards widely accepted; some small places cash only
transit_logic.etiquette: Priority seats for elderly; no eating on subway; stand on right on escalators

scam_alerts: Overpriced skincare in some tourist areas (compare with Olive Young)
Bar hostess tabs in Hongdae/Itaewon with unclear pricing
Unlicensed taxis at airport charging flat high fares
real_time_hacks: T-money card works in convenience stores and some cafés too
Subway has English and is very efficient; avoid rush hour if possible
Olive Young and CU/GS25 for cheap snacks and essentials

cities.name: Mexico City

emergency.health_note: 911 is unified. Private hospitals (e.g. ABC) have English staff; travel insurance advised.

survival_kit.tap_water: Don't drink. Use bottled water; avoid ice from street vendors. Brush teeth with bottled.
survival_kit.power_plug: Type A & B (127V, 60Hz). US plugs work.
survival_kit.tipping: 10-15% in restaurants; round up taxis. Small change for baggers and gas attendants.
survival_kit.toilets: Carry tissue; many public toilets lack it. Cafés and malls are safest.

transit_logic.primary_app: Uber or DiDi; Google Maps. Metro is cheap but very crowded.
transit_logic.payment_method: Cash dominant for taxis and small vendors; card in malls and restaurants
transit_logic.etiquette: Keep bags in front; avoid displaying phones on Metro and in crowds

scam_alerts: Taxi drivers 'without change' or taking long routes
Fake police asking to see wallet or 'check' money
ATM skimmers—use bank lobbies and cover the keypad
real_time_hacks: Uber is safer and often similar price to street taxis; avoid unlicensed cabs
Altitude is 2,240m—take it easy the first day; stay hydrated
Mercados and street food are great but stick to busy, hygienic-looking stalls
